qas.question: What form of music was A cappella predominately used for in its early years?
What was considered part of A cappella until the Baroque period?
The madrigal became what type of form that prevented it from being accompanied with A cappella?
In what era was most of the vocal music considered A cappella?
What was originally used in Renaissance secular vocal music?
What was considered part of a cappella following the Baroque period?
What religions later incoperated a cappella into their traditions?
uring what period was a cappella losinging popularity as religious music?
How was Islamic music originally used?

plausible_answers.text: the majority of secular vocal music

qas.question: What other type of music was considered A capella from the madrigal?
What was considered a form of A capella until the Jewish period?
What is an example of instrumentally accompanied singing?
In what practice what most of the vocal music A capella?

context: <b4_0>A cappella<b4_0/> music was originally used <b8_0>in <a0_0>religious music<b8_0/><a0_0/>, especially church music as well as anasheed and zemirot. <b11_0>Gregorian chant<b11_0/> is an example of a cappella singing, as is <b9_0>the majority of secular vocal music<b9_0/> from <b12_0>the <a3_0><b7_0>Renaissance<b12_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/>. <a1_0><b10_0>The <b5_0>madrigal<b10_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>, up until its development in the early Baroque into an <a2_0>instrumentally-accompanied<a2_0/> form, is also usually in a cappella form. <b6_0>Jewish and Christian<b6_0/> music were originally a cappella,[citation needed] and this practice has continued in both of these religions as well as in Islam.
